title: When will Lebanon's parliament give a vote of confidence to a new government?
preds: It is close to the deadline and no sign of this occurring.
no sign of this happening and very close to deadline
No talks have come forward that indicate advancement.
Revising down given time remaining; no indication this will happen before April 1, 2021.
Considering that it is currently March 18 and no vote has been announced to be anytime soon, it likely will not occur before April 1.

I wonder if this can start to spin fast enough to finally end in bin 3 after all:
"Lebanon's Hariri says priority to form government and re-engage IMF"
https://www.arabnews.com/node/1827681/middle-east As of now, I don't think so.

Lebanon’s Inaction Means Prolonged Depression, Says World Bank Wazni said the government still planned to devalue the currency as part of a transition to a flexible exchange rate, but wouldn’t take that step without an economic reform program and support from the International Monetary Fund to help restore confidence and anchor the pound. “We’re going to a flexible exchange rate but we need an IMF program,” he said.
==================
COMMENT: This is truly sad. The IMF is not going to give them a program if there is no Government, nor the WB.

Things seem to be getting worse in Lebanon.  The nation is scaling back food subsidies and will gradually raise gasoline prices to save dwindling foreign reserves, the caretaker finance minister said.  Few things energize a citizenry in the Middle East more than a cutback on subsidies.  It will be important to watch this over the next few weeks to see if it causes any major changes to the structure of the government.  But for now, I'm adjusting the likelihood nothing gets down by 1 April. The central bank has $16 billion left in foreign reserves, of which only $1 billion to $1.5 billion can be used to fund subsidies, enough for two to three months, Ghazi Wazni said in an interview. Reserves have halved from about $30 billion a year ago. “Lebanon can no longer continue with the same pace of subsidies,” Wazni said, without giving a time frame for the changes. “It costs $500 million a month, $6 billion a year. That’s why the government made the decision to rationalize subsidies and reduce them on some items.” The pound plummeted below 13,000 per dollar on the black market Monday, shedding more than 20% in two weeks. Since anti-government protests erupted in October 2019, the currency has lost nearly 90% of its value, pushing millions into poverty. The inflation rate was 84% last year, with food inflation hitting an annual 402% in December. And quite possibly the MOST important issue: the caretaker cabinet cannot negotiate with the IMF, now essential to unlocking other aid. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-03-16/lebanon-to-reduce-subsidies-as-cash-runs-out-finance-chief-says

Decrementing due time remaining despite the fact this article talks about the current caretaker prime minister threatening to resign in order to pressure the sides to come to an agreement. Though the collapse of the Lebanese pound may exert additional pressure, it still seems unlikely the new government will form before April 1.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-lebanon-crisis/lebanon-on-edge-as-protests-persist-caretaker-pm-pleads-for-new-government-idUSKBN2AY0FZ
https://www.arabnews.com/node/1813386/middle-east No news after that. Only 24 days to go. All in.
There is very little happening in Lebanon that would lead me to believe anything is changing the current deadlock.  I'll adjust this by 1% per week over the remaining time of the forecast.

News reporting continues to indicate that things are not progressing well in Lebanon.    I'm adjusting my likelihood by about 10% to account for the lack of movement. However, this is some growing fervor on the possibility of Lebanon being dragged into the broader violence throughout the Middle East.   - The leader of Lebanon’s influential Christian Maronite church has warned that the country is facing the threat of a “full-fledged coup,” and called for an international conference to avert “chaos, hunger and oppression.”  This is likely related to the ongoing violence in Syria and possible spillover affects.  Al-Rai also called for an international conference to ensure Lebanon’s neutrality, so that it “is no longer a victim of conflicts and wars, and a land of division.”  https://www.arabnews.com/node/1816976/middle-east Growing attention to Iran's actions in Syria could create some momentum for Lebanon to get its act together and form a government.  This issue is worth following closely.

With calls for UN involvement now being made while the President and Prime Minister remain entrenched the chance of proposing and voting on a gov't in 30 days remains very slim.
https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/fpm-tells-hariri-govt-must-be-formed-in-lebanon/ar-BB1e4iJH Additionally, parliamentary elections to fill vacant seats will likely draw out additional delay in a parliamentary vote of confidence.
https://www.arabnews.com/node/1816976/middle-east

Just over two weeks have passed since my original forecast with very little movement.  I'm adjusting by a few points to account for the lack of activity.

and so are the Multinational organizations ....

Parties continuing to declare more tension and separation without even meeting or talking. https://en.abna24.com/news//michel-aoun-saad-hariri-rift-who-is-really-to-blame-for-new-govt-absence-in-lebanon_1112548.html https://english.aawsat.com/home/article/2790121/aoun%E2%80%99s-fpm-acknowledges-its-failure-build-state-fight-corruption-lebanon

Decrementing because President Aoun and Prime Minister Hariri remain light-years apart and no indication Prime Minister Hariri will be removed or step aside. Securing World Bank funding takes pressure of national government to take internal measures to form government.
Some glimmer of hope through indications of impending visit by French President Marcon. An ameliorated US posture to Hezbollah requested and supported by the French could ease some pressure on Lebanese politicians to compromise, however Hezbollah challenges are now deep seated in political leaders minds. https://www.msn.com/en-ae/news/other/kubis-urges-effective-govt-to-rescue-lebanon/ar-BB1ddess https://www.msn.com/en-ae/news/other/kubis-urges-effective-govt-to-rescue-lebanon/ar-BB1ddess

Tremendous amount of turmoil, distrust, and frustration amongst stakeholders: https://www.arabnews.com/node/1797286/middle-east Given the long-time this has historically taken I think that a vote of confidence in next 60 days is highly unlikely.

This was tough to establish a base rate for. It looks like the last time parliment gave a vote of confidence to a new government in Lebanon was in February 2020 (https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/protests-lebanon-ahead-cabinet-vote-confidence-68902041). Prior to that it took them a year to form a government (2019) after having their first parlimentary elections in nine years (2018) (https://www.cfr.org/global-conflict-tracker/conflict/political-instability-lebanon). It looks like Lebanon has announced the formation of a new government (https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2020/1/22/lebanon-announces-formation-of-new-government) but I was unable to find much information on whether a vote of confidence is expected or what that entails. With two months left on this question andongoing demonstrations/protests over the government as well as COVID lockdowns, it seems like there is the potential to negatively impact plans for a vote of confidence. With limited background on Lebanon and how its governed, I'll need to keep my eye on the news to adjust this forecast.

I have a general idea of what a vote of confidence consists of, but not in Lebanon, so I need to do a bit of research! - According to Merriam Webster, a Vote of Confidence is a  formal process in which people (such as the members of a legislature) vote in order to indicate whether or not they support a leader, government, etc. - I know Lebanon has some odd government rules to account for the various religious sects within the country.  According to Brittanica.com: The head of state is the president, who is elected by a two-thirds majority of the National Assembly for a term of six years and is eligible to serve consecutive terms. By an unwritten convention, the president must be a Maronite Christian, the premier a Sunni Muslim, and the speaker of the National Assembly a Shiʿi Muslim. The president, in consultation with the speaker of the National Assembly and the parliamentary deputies, invites a Sunni Muslim to form a cabinet, and the cabinet members’ portfolios are organized to reflect the sectarian balance. The cabinet, which holds more executive power than the president, requires a vote of confidence from the Assembly in order to remain in power. A vote of no confidence, however, is rarely exercised in practice. A cabinet usually falls because of internal dissension, societal strife, or pressure exerted by foreign states. Now it is time to do some research on votes of confidence in Lebanon. - A quick Google Search is returning links with a vote of confidence last occurred in February, 2020.  That is when the Prime Minister in question, Mustafa Diab, received a vote of confidence for his cabinet.  He had been tasked to form a government in December 2019 when the previous prime minister had resigned.  In this case, it took two months from the time a person was chosen until the vote of confidence was taken.  While he has since resigned because of the August bombing, Diab is still acting as the caretaker prime minister.   - In October 2020, Former Lebanese Prime Minister Saad Hariri was tasked with forming his fourth government, winning a slim majority of votes in parliament just under a year after his resignation amid mass-protests last year.  It is now almost February 2021 and the vote of confidence has not yet taken place to confirm Hariri or his cabinet.  The next question is why has the vote of confidence not taken place?  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/10/22/lebanons-saad-hariri-secures-parliamentary-support-to-be-next-pm -It appears that French President Emmanual Macron has been involved trying to get the new government formed.  He has made trips to Lebanon and consults by phone, but no success has been made. - This could take a really long time!  According to the Economist from 2018: LEBANON'S POLITICS operates slowly. It took two and a half years for the country to elect its current president, nine years to hold parliamentary elections and 12 years to pass a budget. The forming of a government appears to obey a similar temporal rule. Lebanon has spent nearly two and a half of the past 13 years without a government, and talks to form a new one have dragged on for over seven months. The country’s Sunni prime minister, Saad Hariri (pictured), said this month that he was hopeful that a new cabinet could be formed before the end of the year.  Bottom line, I see this taking a long time, at by a long time, I mean more than 3 months.   Given all this, I am at 86% that something will not be formed before 1 April and 14% it will occur before 31 March.   The crowd forecast is at 42% and 58%  Wow, I'm way off the crowd!  I need to read some of the comments.  I'm not seeing much in the comments as few people are providing substantive comments.  I need to be selective in who I allow to sway my opinion with the wisdom of the crowd.  I'm going to lower my answers by a bit to conform with the crowd, but not much. I'll continue to look for news and update accordingly.

Lebanon’s political process appears to change quickly and often, making it difficult to establish a base rate of how long it takes new Prime Ministers to form their governments.  In 2009, it took the Prime Minster (PM) eight months to win parliament’s vote of confidence.  Conversely, the previous (PM), appointed in December 2019, took only two months.  The current PM, Saad Hariri, was appointed 22 October 2020.  Simply averaging the two available data points (two months and eight months) would suggest parliament will give a vote of confidence to Hariri’s new government by 31 March 2021. Inside view adjustments.  
Internal politics: Lebanon’s current political and economic situation appears more challenging than it was in 2019.  Lebanon’s previous government resigned in August 2020 following an explosion at the Beirut Port.  This led the President to appoint Hariai as PM.  Hariri is very unpopular and in fact, resigned as PM in 2017.  He has pledged to form a government of politically elite technocrats, which angered several of the dominate political factions.  Most importantly, Hezbollah and it’s allies strongly oppose Hariai’s approach.  Hezbollah’s support was critical to gaining a quick vote of confidence in 2019.  Absent Hezbollah’s backing, the current process will likely take much longer, as it did in 2009.  This shifts my forecast further from the outside view to eight months (June 2021).  Economic pressure: Many middle east experts argue Lebanon’s current economic and fiscal situation is the worst it has been since the 1975-1990 civil war.  This deteriorating situation has led France and World Bank to take an active interest in Lebanon’s economic stability.  Both have called for political as well as economic reforms as conditions for badly needed financial aid.  Lebabon’s need for external assistance may drive internal compromise, however, involving a third party to internal political issues will undoubtedly add more time to the process of selecting and certifying a government.  Absent additional information, I expect the benefit of external pressure will balance with the delays of external coordination and have a net negligible effect on my eight-month forecast.

The government formation process is being held up by both personal insults and political disagreements PM designee was insulted by video footage of President calling PMd a liar. The primary policy difference is President's insistence that Interior and Justice ministries not be controlled by the PMd's party.  Most variables are internal to the country (sectarian politics), but two external variables could influence the speed of parliamentary approval- pressure from the World Bank or France. I believe neither will have significant effect on the process. One outcome is the Pmd and President agree on a slate of ministers and another outcome is that PMd withdraws from forming a government. It's unlikely he will withdraw and unlikely outside pressure has any great effect on the formation process. There's been almost no progress in January and President has upper hand in blocking PMd candidates because the population's expectations for resolution are low.

Outside View: A vote of confidence appears to happen after regular election cycles, the last was in Feb 2020. The PM resigned after the port blast last August, and Mustapha Adib, the PM-designate, couldn’t do it and stepped aside in 26 Sep 2020. The former PM Hariri is now attempting to form a government, but faces significant opposition. Inside View: Lebanon has a debt crisis, inflation, currency devaluation (80%), and it’s economy is very poor off. It had the Aug explosion in the port areas that killed many and flattned several blocks. Lately, there have been protests about COVID restrictions and government corruption, especially in the Tripoli area where many politicians live.  There has been pressure from Emmanuel Macron of France and others. Hezbollah states it will agree to form a govt only if it has 1/3 the cabinet, with foreign affairs and security in its portfolio.  Synthesis: Since Hezbollah’s demands are very high, it seems unlikely that a new government will be formed. 80% after April 1, 20% b/w 1 Feb and March 31.

It is possible that the delay in the Lebanonese formation of a new government is do in part to incompetence and in part to geopolitical issues. The Iran Nuclear deal may play a part, where Iran want maximum leverage to negotiate if talks resume with the new Biden administration. the following comments could be an indication of this:
"Progressive Socialist Party leader ex-MP Walid Jumblat said Lebanon is under “Iranian tutelage”, and that the formation of a government is delayed because the Free Patriotic Movement and Hizbullah did not receive the green light yet, al-Anbaa electronic magazine reported."
http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/278842 "Nasrallah reiterated on Sunday Iranian President Hassan Rouhani’s statement that Iran is willing to negotiate with Washington about returning to the 2015 so-called nuclear deal, but that Iran's influence over regional proxies and Tehran's ballistic missile program would not be part of those negotiations."
https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/12/hezbollah-israel-missiles-lebanon.html Lebanon seems to be uniquely incompetent to form a government in the fall out of the port explosion and erroding economic position. "Video footage was broadcast on Jan. 11 of a meeting between Aoun and the caretaker prime minister, Hassan Diab, in which Aoun accused Hariri of lying when he claimed that his proposed government lineup had been approved. Commentators have claimed that, in doing so, Aoun insulted the office of prime minister and head of government, thus widening the gulf between the president and the prime minister-designate. Over the past 10 days, several attempts to bridge that gap have failed." “The World Bank is greatly concerned and feels a responsibility to help to form the government,” Jha told Lebanon’s Central News Agency. “Things are getting worse every day.”
https://www.arabnews.com/node/1796836/middle-east

Little time remaining so I'm depleting by end of January, seems highly unlikely a cabinet is formed and approved by parliament in that timeframe. There are some positive recent news articles, so I'm keeping higher confidence in February to March. But I thought that about earlier categories too, so leaving plenty of uncertainty for the last bucket. The process so far has appeared to be highly dysfunctional.

Major decisions have been set to one side amid the political paralysis, notably what to do about subsidies on basic goods including fuel, which are being imported using the central bank’s dwindling foreign currency reserves. The deadlock has also obstructed a French initiative aimed at addressing the crisis. President Emmanuel Macron is due to visit Lebanon later this month, his third trip since the blast. A senior political source said most parties were not really satisfied with the line-up presented by Hariri, though their complaints were “limited to a certain portfolio or name”." https://www.reuters.com/article/lebanon-crisis-government/lebanons-jumblatt-sees-no-white-smoke-soon-on-government-idUSKBN28J27W

On the contrary the vote of confidence has taken longer for every new government. 2009 it took only on day where 2019 it took 20 days.
Hariri began consultations with the president on a draft cabinet list. Increasing odds of success in December a bit.

The one political driver which would encourage empaneling a cabinet before 31 Jan is the incoming US administration. If Biden is in WH on 20 Jan, will the Lebanese cabinet want to have all this hashed out before then? Seems to me Iran and Saudi Arabia would want to have their slates as clean as possible before engaging with the new administration and settling political disputes in Lebanon would fit that mold.

It seems they are close and very far apart, depending on what you are looking at. From a Lebanese political situation, its seems they could be close. "After a two-week hiatus, Prime Minister-designate Saad Hariri is expected to meet with President Michel Aoun soon to present him with a draft Cabinet lineup in an attempt to break the weekslong government deadlock, political sources said Sunday.
An official source said no date has been set yet for a meeting between Aoun and Hariri in the coming week. “When Hariri wants to come to Baabda, he will call and come,” the source told The Daily Star."
https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/economy/story/Hariri_said_to_present_first_draft__Lebanese_Cabinet_lineup-SNG_191271563/ "The source said that when Hariri visits Baabda Palace, “he will definitely carry with him a draft Cabinet lineup,” his first since he was designated to form a new government on Oct. 22.
“But lingering differences between Aoun and Hariri over naming the Christian ministers is posing a major hindrance to the Cabinet formation,” the source said."

Nader told Al-Monitor that Lebanon’s government formation is a pressure point from Iran against Western countries and particularly the United States since Hezbollah is the most powerful party in Lebanon and can decide whether a government gets formed. He added, “The Lebanese-Israeli maritime border negotiations was a plan B for Hezbollah in case [Donald] Trump was elected president, and it is no coincidence that these negotiations have stopped now that Biden is the president-elect.”

Updating since time is running out on 1 Dec.  No real updates in the past month.

Significantly downgrading my optimistic view from a couple weeks ago.  Govt formation by 1 Dec seems a near impossibility at this point.  No significant headway has been made to form a cabinet, let alone hold a vote of confidence.  Next month's aid conference co-chaired by Macron and the UNSG may put additional pressure on Hariri to get a government formed, but my level of confidence isn't particularly high.  It is unclear from this outsider's perspective exactly what will break the logjam.
Depleting before Dec 1, time is nearly out and no news of progress from a brief search. Before January 31 looks most likely I think.
It is well to remember that "vote of confidence" is a technical term and does not reflect anybody's actual feeling of confidence in anybody else.  Stay tuned.

"BEIRUT, Nov 26 (Reuters) - Lebanon's caretaker finance minister said on Thursday that central bank foreign currency reserves currently stand at $17.9 billion and that there are discussions about reducing subsidy spending as critically low reserves dwindle.
Ghazi Wazni said in an interview with local broadcaster LBCI that he supported gradually rationalising spending on subsidies until a new government is formed that enacts long-demanded reforms to unlock foreign financial assistance.
Lebanon is grappling with a deep economic and financial crisis that has hammered the currency, spread poverty and prompted a sovereign debt default.
An official source had told Reuters that only $800 million in foreign currency reserves were available for subsidising key imports such as fuel, wheat and medicine until the end of 2020."[...]
"Wazni said the formation of a new government was direly needed to address the deepening crisis. He said unemployment in Lebanon had reached more than 40%."

Beirut, Nov 2 (Prensa Latina) Optimism about the rapid establishment of a Government in Lebanon has vanished overnight due to the insurmountable demands by political parties, local media commented on Monday. Efforts by Designated Prime Minister Saad Hariri found obstacles imposed by the Free Patriotic Movement, the Lebanese Democratic Party and the Marada Movement, which demand more positions in the new Government or at least one ministry. The dispute focuses on three key ministries (Interior, Defense and Justice), so the process is in square one again, according to the Naharnet website. Other posts that are causing trouble in the distribution are the ministries linked to public services, such as Health, Public Works, Education and Social Affairs. So, the distribution of posts in the future Government with a design of 18 ministers: nine for Muslims and nine for Christians, seems to be in danger.
https://www.plenglish.com/index.php?o=rn&id=61412&SEO=optimism-about-rapid-establishment-of-government-in-lebanon-vanishes

Lebanon typically struggles to form a government quickly based on the power sharing arrangement between religious factions. According to the economist as of early 2019  (https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2018/12/21/why-lebanon-struggles-to-form-governments) the country has had 2.5 years out of the previous 13 without a government. However, the reemergence of Hariri as a potential PM following Adib's stepping down seems to indicate hope for a somewhat quicker solution in this case. Still, any of a number of parties (including Hezbollah) could exercise its veto stymieing progress. International pressure by France could encourage action to ensure financial guarantees. BL- there are a lot of competing interests and time pressures, but that hasn't seemed to make for quick government formations on avg in the past, so I expect a long timeline here as well.

- Base rate: Government formation routinely takes several months in Lebanon. 
- The current prime minister, Hassan Diab, resigned August 10 following the explosion at the Beirut port. Diab continues as a caretaker. Parties have not agreed to a new government despite an attempt to form one around Lebanon ambassador to Germany Mustafa Adib. Adib stepped down on September 26 amid the deadlock over government formation. It's difficult to see how the incentives for the parties to form a government will change before the end of the year. 
- Lebanon's confesionalist power sharing structure gives Hezbollah a veto over any new government. 
- France and the United States have been publicly at odds over Lebanon. French President Macron has dangled debt relief (IMF, other donors) in return for reform in Lebanon. However, the United States has taken a much harder line against any negotiations with Hezbollah (and Iran). Hezbollah may believe the negotiating environment will be more favorable under a Biden administration. With Biden leading in US polls, Hezbollah will wait to see who wins the election. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/oct/11/there-is-no-hope-the-slow-disintegration-of-lebanon
https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/04/middleeast/iraq-lebanon-us-elections-intl/index.html
https://www-economist-com.nduezproxy.idm.oclc.org/the-economist-explains/2018/12/21/why-lebanon-struggles-to-form-governments

Based on the dire economic situation and the contingency of European aid on a new government Lebanon must install a new government as soon as possible.  Usual political shenanigans could delay the formation until past December but it is not likely.

The closest base rate I can determine for time for parliament to vote on a new government is approximately 10 months. However it appears, parliament votes more frequently than just during election cycles.
Lebanon has three factors for forming the current government - pending debt payments, French political involvement, and post explosion corruption charges.
All point to a significant delay in forming a government. French's involvement is to avoid religiously affiliated political parties from participating in a caretaker government. Absolutely no indication that will be achievable or supported by a parliamentary vote.
Debt payments were defaulted in March 2020. I have been unable to find when the next payment is due, however IMF has suspended negotiations on a debt payment since July due to unsatisfactory progress and now without a government to negotiate with there will be no progress. This could be a driver for getting a government formed, however meeting IMF demands to relieve debt payment - most likely ending a large number of subsidies - will likely not be supported by the citizens or parliament.
The recent explosion has resulted in the arrest of 25 officials however no investigation results have been released and protests indicate citizens continue to demand change to historic political system that allowed mismanagement to reach point of the devastating explosion.
The next election is not scheduled until 2022, but an early election could be called. Lebanon's last scheduled election was delayed over 3 yrs so any call for early elections will likely not result in a gov't getting formed in the next 6 months.

- Parliament is divided between 18 religious groups.
-  Lebanon has spent 2.5 years of the past 13 without a government 
- Lebanon formed a state of emergency on 13 Aug
-Macron warned that if real reforms don’t happen, including in the banking sector and at the central bank, France could impose punitive sanctions on the ruling class. 
- President Michel Aoun has called for binding consultations with members of parliament this week to name a new prime minister, after appointing a PM a government still needs to be established. Seems to be a 1-3 month process. 
-  Current economic conditions and threatened sanctions will increase the need for the establishment of a new government.

Since 2008, the seven changes of parliament have taken anywhere from two weeks to 9 months for an average of four months to gain a vote of confidence for a new government.  The nine month span was most recent in 2019.  The deteriorating circumstances in the country will provide greater incentive for Lebanon's government and the international community to see this through.  Lebanon needs the new parliament to secure much needed international assistance.  @SE_Meyer Also, President Aoun and Speaker Berri's willingness to meet with former Prime Minister Hariri (who is willing to re-take the seat) is promising.  If it is Hariri, it took him five months on his first attempt and nine months on his second attempt to get a vote of confidence.   Also, the sectarian divide is significant in the government (Hezbollah is making the process increasingly difficult) and the world itself is facing more and more nationalism/populism, and government reform.  There is a small chance that a Muslim majority in Lebanon replaces in the system of confessionals in place.

Given how complicated the Lebanese political landscape is, for now I'm just trying to come up with a base rate.  
The last time there was a major turnover of power, it took 3 months from Saad Hariri's resignation as PM in Oct 2019 until a new government was seated in Jan 2020. After the August 4 port explosion, PM Diab announced he was stepping down, but asked to stay on for two months in order to get a new government in place.  But he only lasted about a month, and left.   Then the premier designate, Mustapha Adib, stepped down on Sept 26, citing how difficult it was to get a government pulled together.   So let's assume it takes at least 2-3 months (given recent experiences) to get a new government in place.  If we start the clock with Adib's departure at the end of September, then maybe a new government would be voted in by parliament at the end of December. This is a very simplistic analysis given the fact that the economy is tanking, how historically divisive and factionalized Lebanese politics are, and the unrest in the population, but at least it's a starting point.  Among the factors that might create some pressure for the parliament to speed it up is that Macron is pressuring them to do so.

Per Lebanon's President, consultations for a new PM will start 15 Oct.  This is after the last attempt to form a government failed in September.  The political leaders seem to be highly partisan and not talking to each other.  Macron has continued to put pressure on the nation to form a government.  Due to the dire economic/banking situation, the Lebanese people could either pressure the parliament to work together or devolve into civil war.  A lot of unknowns.  The distribution of seats based on religion created a highly fragmented parliament which makes it difficult to form a government, but the fact that funds are being withheld until a government is formed could force a government to form in order to prevent a civil war.

If history in Lebanon is any indicator, the last government took 2.5 years to elect a President, 9 years to elect the Parliament and 12 to pass a budget.  Sectarian divides are deeper than ever which will make this task a long one. Despite the French President's ultimatum of withholding financial aid or imposing sanctions on the leading elite over the next three months, the economic crisis will not be enough to motivate a vote of confidence in a new government.

Next important date is October 15 where there will consultations to see who will be tapped as a potential prime minister to try and corm a government.

The deep sectarian lines drawn in Lebanon make it so that transitions of power and the forming of new governments will likely take a long and tumultuous path before giving a new vote of confidence.
Lebanon is not historically fast moving in this arena.  Will the current turmoil and unrest speed the process along?  I don't' think it will.  There seems to be little trust in the governing elite.

- Outside view – historically it has taken Lebanon many months to form a cabinet (2019 – eight months, 2014 – ten months.  As of December 2018, Lebanon had spent 2.5 out of the last 13 years without a government).
- It’s highly unlikely Lebanon will be able to form a cabinet before November 3 U.S. presidential elections.  Pompeo has criticized Macron’s engagement with Hizballah and the U.S. imposed sanctions on Hizballah allies.  U.S. is not supporting France’s diplomatic push.
- The Iranian and Saudi backed factions have dug in.  Plus, the West has preconditioned billions of dollars of aid on the creation of the government and subsidies of basic goods could soon end, leading to economic disaster and possibly more unrest. https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2018/12/21/why-lebanon-struggles-to-form-governments

Progress seems stalled, and it seems without strong international pressure, this may not advance quickly.
Upping the before December bucket and December to January buckets a bit based on other comments showing that it's unusual for government formation to take exceedingly long.

Apparently it took about 9 months in early 2019. A few months again around late 2019. But Macron has been putting increased international pressure on the Lebanese politicians to form a government and fix the ongoing issues in the country which have been exacerbated by the explosion. Hard to say what will happen, I think there's a decent chance it happens in the next few months but lots of uncertainty. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-47080597 https://www.arabnews.com/node/1597986

With the Shia mini-state within Lebanon having no interest in co-operating, plus the continuing decay of Lebanon's unique power-sharing arrangement between the different ethnic and religious groups, the outlook is bleak. Macron might have to pull off a diplomatic coup worthy of the Nobel Peace Prize to achieve this before the end of year. Hope he does so because things could well worse before they improve. Economic assistance will pour in regardless of when a government is formed and this could well mean self-interest trumps the national interest. Useful analysis here: https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-54307896

Forming a new government typically takes approximately 4 months in the past ten years, with a typical range of 1 to 5 months. This would put the outer most time frame at in January. There is international attention and financial incentive to install a new government quickly. Macron has extended his deadline to allow for another 4-6 weeks in order to secure the financial aid package. This puts a requirement to put together a government by November 8, 2020.
